title: Cardi B's best burns in her new role as Netflix’s rap competition judge
text:
CLOSE Dressed head-to-toe in tweed, Cardi B attended the Chanel show in Paris where a faux Parisian rooftop acted as the catwalk (Oct. 1) AP Entertainment

Netflix’s hip-hop competition show “Rhythm + Flow” (streaming Wednesday), has that familiar reality TV format: Auditions in separate cities, celebrity judges announced with plenty of fanfare, forced banter, emotional backstories and dramatic eliminations.

But it also has something “American Idol” and “America’s Got Talent” lack: The quotable commentary of Cardi B.

And since the streaming show isn’t beholden to primetime broadcast rules, it has a few other things “The Voice” fans haven’t seen before: Contestants rapping their own expletive-laden lyrics, sexual references (often from Cardi), judges drinking and smoking onstage and episodes released in weekly batches. Also, in the first episode, slain rapper Nipsey Hussle makes one of his final appearances, coaching aspiring musicians at 1500 Sound Academy in Inglewood, California.

Cardi B brings plenty of quotable commentary and colorful hairstyles to Netflix's hip-hop competition "Rhythm + Flow." (Photo: Eddy Chen/Netflix)

Cardi B. stars alongside T.I., who serves as the sophisticated record-producer judge – with his upturned chin and dignified nods of approval – and Chance the Rapper, the friendly smiley emoji come to life who apologizes even when delivering quiet and gentle criticism.

But it’s Cardi who lights up the room, with a fresh hair color in each location and a novel quip for every contestant. “I’m paid to be the mean one,” she says with a twinkle in her eye and a fruity cocktail in her hand.

Cardi B’s best lines from the “Rhythm + Flow” auditions

To Inglewood IV, who ended his song with shouts of “Murder! Murder! Murder!”: “I really wasn’t feeling that murder thing. You know that scares white people.”

To artist CNG after he didn’t move much onstage: “Imagine you’re performing in the strip club. People are going to look at you like (appears bored). ‘Cause you don’t wanna be a snooze fest.”

To the less-than-emotive Streeb: “I was really likin’ what you said, but I just wanted it to touch me a little bit more. I want you to touch me... Oh, no no, I’m married, I have children!”

To the bespectacled, makeup-free Rae Khalil: “I like you. You’re very different from me. I’m selling boobs, I’m selling (butt) and everything. But if I was to hear your song, I wouldn’t even care. I’d still like it.”

To fat rapper J-Pex: "You know what Fat Joe, Big Pun, Rick Ross, Biggie all have in common? They have this confidence and they have this swag that make skinny (guys) wanna be them, that make (girls) wanna lick icing off they stomachs."

The fast-rapping Marcaux: “I like your flow. Am I gonna remember you later on when I’m (having sex)? No.”

To the confident, loud-talking Nas B: “Let’s say if I was a label, and I give you money. I don’t wanna make people mad because you ain't give them back they money.”

To Steven Bonus, who was wearing a flannel shirt and glasses: “You really surprise me, because you look like you work in Best Buy.”

To Ant Beale, whose nipples showed through his mesh shirt: “When it comes to you, you didn’t stab my heart, but you sliced it. I need you to stab me. You (just) pierced the nipple."

To fresh-faced Kay Makavel: “Are you gonna make me some money? Because when you go into a label, these white folks be like (strokes an imaginary beard). They need to see the whole S sign with the whole ca-ching on it.”

To the bilingual, jumpsuit-clad D Smoke: “When I saw you, you look like you was gonna wash the floor, (but) you can write for me if you want to.”

And to T.I., after he described something as having an “intangible benefit”: “How do you know all of these fancy words?” His reply: “I’ve been to prison, Cardi. I’ve spent a lot of time reading dictionaries.”
